title-group.article-title: On the dynamics of a beam with switching crack and damaged boundaries

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Science and Engineering, University of Illinois at Urbana – Champaign, Urbana, USA
2Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, New Mexico State University, Las Cruces, USA

author-notes.corresp: Mohammad A AL-Shudeifat, Department of Mechanical Science and Engineering, University of Illinois at Urbana – Champaign, 1206 West Green Street, Urbana, IL 61801, USA Email: shdefat@illinois.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The local equivalent linear stiffness method (LELSM), which has previously been found to be efficient in predicting the modal behavior of nonlinear structural dynamic systems with cubic and dead-zone nonlinearities, is applied to a beam with a switching crack where the crack is modeled as a nonsmooth (clearance) nonlinearity. In addition, the LELSM is also applied for the boundary damage of the beam where the damage is modeled via smooth (cubic) nonlinearity, while a new technique for finding the global equivalent bilinear stiffness matrix (GEBSM) is introduced here to be applied to the systems with clearance nonlinearity or switching stiffness. As a result, the GEBSM of the system of concern is formulated based on the approximated analytical values of the bilinear frequencies of the system. For a system with mixed clearance and cubic nonlinearities, the GEBSM is found first for the clearance nonlinearity, and then the LELSM is subsequently applied to update the GEBSM for finding the global equivalent linear stiffness matrix (GELSM) of the system. It is found that the GEBSM and GELSM modes, for which no a priori simulation is required, closely approximate the corresponding proper orthogonal modes for either a vanishing clearance or a small nonvanishing clearance.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Damage detection in structural dynamic systems has mostly depended on selecting an appropriate damage model. In general, damage in structural systems such as beams is characterized by the change in the natural frequencies and the mode shapes of the system. Hence, different techniques and assumptions have been used in modeling the damage in beams that are mostly based on the stiffness change in the damaged area. In Chondros (2001), the partial differential equation for the flexural vibration of the Euler–Bernoulli beam with transverse crack has been derived by assuming that the beam with a breathing crack is a piecewise-linear system. Hence, the frequencies of the system can be approximated via the bilinear frequency formula. The experimental frequencies were found to be close to the theoretical results of the effective bilinear frequency formula. The transverse edge crack in a cantilever beam was considered by Chati et al. (1997) where the nonlinearity in the system, which appears due to the crack, was also modeled as a piecewise-linear system. By assuming two linear cases of the crack (fully open case and fully closed case), the bilinear frequency formula of the cracked system was derived. The numerical results of the finite element model (FEM) of the cracked system have been used to calculate the effective bilinear frequencies of the first three mode shapes. The authors have investigated a two-degree-of-freedom piecewise-linear system and their results for this system demonstrated that the bilinear frequency formula is a good approximation to the effective frequencies of the damaged beam. The bilinear vibration behavior was also considered by Luo and Wu (2006) by deriving the bilinear period of the vibration of a cracked beam where the results have been compared with those of Chondros (2001) and Chati et al. (1997) where a good agreement has been observed.

In many studies, the FEM of a cracked structure has been numerically simulated to obtain the eigenparameters of the damaged system. The switching crack (fully open state or fully closed state) in Qian et al. (1990) has been considered for a clamped-free beam where the finite element stiffness matrix of the cracked element was derived by integrating the stress intensity factors. A full FEM of the system has been numerically simulated. The results have shown the variations in the first three critical frequencies with crack depth at different locations. In Pandey et al. (1991), the stiffness matrix of the damaged beam has been formulated by assuming that the change in the stiffness in the damaged element was due to the reduction in the modulus of elasticity of that element. The FEM of the system was numerically simulated to obtain the mode shapes that had been used to obtain the curvature mode shapes. The difference between the intact beam and the damaged beam curvature mode shape was found to be useful in locating the damaged area of the beam. The crack in a simply supported beam in Narkis (1994) has been modeled by an equivalent linear spring that connects two parts of the beam at the crack location. The equation of motion of the flexural vibration of a uniform beam was used with this crack model, where the method of separation of variables was used in solving the equation of motion. The resulting equations were used to solve the inverse problem to calculate the frequencies based on the bending or axial vibration data. The results have shown that this technique is sufficient in showing the variations in the first two natural frequencies due to different crack locations.

Other methods have been used for damage detection in beams based on different crack modeling techniques. Principal orthogonal decomposition (POD) was used by Galvanetto and Violaris (2007), where the damage was quantified and located by finding the difference between the proper orthogonal modes (POMs) of the undamaged and damaged beam. The POD, based on the principal component analysis (PCA) of the damaged structure, was also used by Yan et al. (2005) for structural damage detection in varying environmental conditions. The node residual force vector in Yang and Liu (2007), which is found via algebraic solution of the residual force equation, was used in damage identification in the truss structure. The minimum rank update theory has been employed by Zimmerman and Kaouk (1994) for structural dynamic damage detection. The modal strain energy change has been used by Shi et al. (2000) in damage detection of a steel structure, where it was found that this technique can localize single and multiple damages locations. The variable cross-section beam with a damaged boundary and with or without follower forces was studied by Sari and Butcher (2010), where the damage was modeled via linear and torsional springs. The resulting algebraic eigenvalue problem obtained by the application of the shifted Chebyshev polynomials was solved for the eigenvalues of the damaged beam, while the damage was found to have a larger effect on the frequencies of the higher modes than the lower modes. The nonlinear forced response of the piecewise-linear cracked plate with multiple discontinuities was studied by Saito and Epureanu (2011), where a set of bilinear modes (BLMs) at special boundary conditions has been found to well approximate the set of the dominant POMs of the system. This approximated set of BLMs was used for model order reduction of the bilinear system, which was found to be comparable to the traditional methods of model order reduction. Empirical mode decomposition (EMD) was applied by Rezaei and Taheri (2010) to the numerical and experimental vibration response of a cracked cantilevered steel beam with a transverse notch crack. The EMD energy damage parameter was found to be an efficient tool for damage detection and quantification in cracked cantilever beams. An efficient experimental approach was introduced by Hamey et al. (2004) in which piezoelectric sensors were used to capture the curvature mode shapes for detecting the damage in a damaged carbon/epoxy composites beam. The low-order nonlinear normal forms were applied to a cantilever beam with a notch crack in Nataraju et al. (2005), where the damages in the beam have been modeled as bifurcations in the stable equilibrium points.

Beam systems with a switching crack and damaged boundary are considered in this study. The local equivalent linear stiffness method (LELSM) in Butcher (1999), Butcher and Lu (2007), AL-Shudeifat and Butcher (2010) and Butcher and AL-Shudeifat (2011) is employed with the bilinear frequency approach in the modal analysis of the cracked beam with the damaged boundary where mixed nonlinearities appear. The mixed nonlinearities include the switching crack clearance nonlinearity and the cubic nonlinearity at the damaged boundary. Two methods have been developed in this study for finding the global equivalent bilinear stiffness matrix (GEBSM) of a cracked beam with a switching crack and of an illustrative spring-mass system with clearance nonlinearity (switching stiffness) based on the analytical values of the bilinear frequencies of these systems. In addition, the GEBSM is used with the LELSM for finding the local equivalent linear stiffness of the nonlinear spring for the system with mixed nonlinearities, where it is updated to the global equivalent linear stiffness matrix (GELSM), which includes the effect of both clearance and cubic nonlinearities. The accuracy of the GEBSM and GELSM modes is verified through their close approximation to the corresponding POMs of the systems considered. In addition, the bilinear frequencies are calculated for the GEBSM and compared with the corresponding analytical values of these bilinear frequencies, where an excellent agreement has been observed.

sec.title: 2. The local equivalent linear stiffness method and global equivalent bilinear stiffness matrix
sec.p:
The updated LELSM modes have been previously found to be efficient in approximating the POMs of nonlinear dynamic systems, with symmetric cubic and dead-zone nonlinearities, in AL-Shudeifat and Butcher (2010) and Butcher and AL-Shudeifat (2011). Similarly, this method is explored here for finding the local equivalent linear stiffness of the bilinear clearance nonlinearity. By finding such a local equivalent stiffness, the equivalent linear stiffness matrix Keq is obtained for the undamped and unforced nonlinear system. It is desired here to find a local equivalent linear stiffness corresponding to the jth degree of freedom of the nonlinear spring-mass system shown in Figure 1(a). The undamped equation of motion of the mass mj is given as (1)mjx··j+(kj+kj+1)xj+fnl j(xj)-kjxj-1-kj+1xj+1=0 where fnl j(xj)={0;x1<xckc(xj-xc);x1>xc Figure 1.
(a) The nonlinear n-degree-of-freedom vibrating spring-mass system with clearance nonlinearity. (b) The nonlinear single-degree-of-freedom spring-mass system. (c), (d) Local equivalent linear systems to the nonlinear system in (b).

As in AL-Shudeifat and Butcher (2010) and Butcher and AL-Shudeifat (2011), the LELSM requires setting the coordinates of the degrees of freedom j-1 and j+1 to zero, which yields the single degree-of-freedom nonlinear system (2)mjx··j+(kj+kj+1)xj+fnl j(xj)=0 as shown in Figure 1(b).

An exact expression for the nonlinear frequency of the single degree-of-freedom system in Equation (2) was derived by Butcher (1999) as (3)Ω=2ω-[1+2πsin-1ρ+1α(1-2πsin-1(ρα1-ρ2(1-1/α2)))]-1 where ω-=(kj+kj+1)/mj is the frequency of the system in Figure 1(b) in the first linear sub-region xj≤xc, ω+=(kj+kj+1+kc)/mj is the frequency of this system in the second linear sub-region xc<xj and α=ω+/ω- and ρ=xc/xj(0) are dimensionless parameters. For a vanishing clearance, Equation (3) becomes the well-known bilinear frequency relation, as in Chati et al. (1997): (4)Ω=2ω-ω+ω-+ω+

The equations of motion of the local equivalent linear single degree-of-freedom systems in Figures 1(c) and (d), respectively, are given as (5)mjx··j+(kj+kj+1+k∧eq)xj=0 or (6)x··j+(keq)jmjxj≡0 where kj+kj+1+k∧eq=(keq)j=mjΩ2, where Ω is obtained from Equation (3) or Equation (4). Hence, the nonlinear equation of motion of mj in the n-degree-of-freedom system is approximated as (7)mjx··j+(keq)jxj-kjxj-1-kj+1xj+1=0
Therefore, the linear equivalent stiffness matrix using the LELSM is given by (8)Keq=[k1+k2-k2-k2k2+k3-k30-kj(keq)j-kj+10-kn-1kn-1+kn-kn-knkn]

The linear equivalent stiffness matrix in Equation (8) was updated via an iteration technique in AL-Shudeifat and Butcher (2010) and Butcher and AL-Shudeifat (2011). This technique was used to update the initial condition until the LELSM mode closely converged to the corresponding POM. The resulting modes were found to closely approximate the POMs of systems with either cubic or dead-zone nonlinearities.

In addition, the piecewise modal method (PMM) in Butcher (1999) approximates the bilinear normal mode frequencies in the ith mode from two separate sets of eigenfrequencies ω-i (the ith mode frequency of the system in the first linear sub-region xj≤xc) and ω+i (the ith mode frequency of the system in the second linear sub-region xc<xj) for a nonvanishing clearance by analogy to Equation (3) as (9)Ωi=2ω-i[1+2πsin-1ρ+1γi(1-2πsin-1(ργi1-ρ2(1-1/γi2)))]-1 where γi=ω+i/ω-i. For a vanishing clearance, Equation (9) becomes (10)Ωi=2ω-iω+iω-i+ω+i
Equation (10) was used by Chati et al. (1997) to obtain approximate bilinear frequencies for a cracked beam with vanishing clearance at the crack.

The updated LELSM modes are found for the system in Figure 2, where the masses and stiffnesses are set to unity, in appropriate units, except for the clearance stiffness kc, which is selected to be kc=0.1. The modal amplitude X20 of the end mass m20 of the first linear mode is used as the initial amplitude for calculating ρ where ρ=xc/X20. From Equation (3), the equivalent stiffness for m20 is calculated from (keq)j=kj+kj+1+k∧eq=mjΩ2. The linear equivalent system for the nonlinear system in Figure 2 is shown in Figure 3. Figure 2.
The 20-degrees-of-freedom spring-mass system with classic clearance nonlinearity.
Figure 3.
The equivalent linear system of the 20-degrees-of-freedom spring-mass system with classic vanishing or nonvanishing clearance nonlinearity.

The POD method is used here for finding the POMs, which are computed from the response of the nonlinear dynamic system. The POM is the best linear approximation to the corresponding nonlinear normal modes (NNM) of the nonlinear system when the system oscillates at this NNM, as described by Feeny and Kappagantu (1998), Kerschen and Golinval (2002) and Kerschen et al. (2005), while in Rand (1974), the NNM itself is a synchronous periodic motion of the undamped nonlinear dynamic system. For the damped nonlinear dynamic systems, Shaw and Pierre (1991) use a two-dimensional invariant manifold. In this paper, the systems of concern with either clearance or mixed cubic and clearance nonlinearities have been simulated using Runge–Kutta methods for finding the time history matrix to obtain the POMs, which are used to verify the accuracy of the suggested techniques in this paper compared with these POMs.

It is found that, unlike the cases of cubic and dead-zone nonlinearities, the updated LELSM modes for the system in Figure 2 are not accurate in approximating the POMs of the systems with clearance nonlinearity, as shown in Figure 4 for different values of clearance stiffness. As a result, a new method is introduced in this paper to deal with nonlinear dynamic systems with clearance nonlinearity, such as a beam with a transverse switching crack. This method is based on the following steps.
Calculate the set of n approximate values of the bilinear frequencies (Ωi, i=1,2,…,n) of the system with clearance nonlinearity using the PMM from Equation (9) for the nonvanishing clearance or Equation (10) for the vanishing clearance.
Find the equivalent linear stiffness k∧eq such that 0<k∧eq<kc, for which the n×n mass-normalized stiffness matrix in Equation (8) has n approximate eigenfrequencies Ω~i for i=1,2,…,n such that ∑i=1nwi|Ωi-Ω~i| is minimized via numerical iteration on k∧eq in Equation (8). wi are weights that can be selected to give more or less accuracy to various modes.
As the optimum value of k∧eq is obtained by iteration, the stiffness matrix in Equation (8) is now updated to obtain the GEBSM. This is not equal to the LELSM in general.
The modes of the equivalent linear system with the mass-normalized GEBSM are compared with the corresponding updated LELSM modes and the POMs of the system.
Figure 4.
Comparison between the first updated local equivalent linear stiffness method (LELSM) mode with the first proper orthogonal mode (POM) of the nonlinear 20-degrees-of-freedom nonlinear dynamic system with clearance nonlinearity.

The approximate bilinear frequencies calculated using the PMM in Equation (9) for γi=ω+i/ω-i are compared with the GEBSM frequencies for different values of xc in Figure 5. It is shown that the approximate bilinear frequencies of the system using the PMM and GEBSM are nearly equal for the vanishing clearance, while the difference slightly increases as the nonvanishing clearance increases, especially for the higher modes frequencies. In addition, the first GEBSM mode is compared with the first POM when the first linear mode is chosen as initial condition, as shown in Figure 6 for different values of the clearance xc. It is found that the increase in the nonvanishing clearance slightly increases the error in approximating the first POM by the first GEBSM mode. The equivalent stiffness keq for the GEBSM is shown in Table 1 for each case in Figure 5. It is shown in Figure 7 that the accuracy of approximating the POMs by the GEBSM modes decreases as the value of kc is increased. Figure 5.
Comparison between the frequencies of the mass-normalized global equivalent bilinear stiffness matrix (GEBSM) found via the approximate bilinear frequencies calculated via the piecewise modal method (PMM) in Equation (9) for kc=0.1 in the 20-degrees-of-freedom spring-mass system in Figure 2 with (a) vanishing clearance and (b)–(d) nonvanishing clearance.
Figure 6.
Comparison between the first mass-normalized global equivalent bilinear stiffness matrix (GEBSM) mode and the first proper orthogonal mode (POM) for kc=0.1 in the 20-degrees-of-freedom spring-mass system in Figure 2 with (a) vanishing clearance and (b)–(d) nonvanishing clearance.
Figure 7.
Comparison between the first mass-normalized global equivalent bilinear stiffness matrix (GEBSM) mode with the first proper orthogonal mode (POM) of the nonlinear 20-degrees-of-freedom nonlinear dynamic system in Figure 2 for vanishing clearance for different values of the clearance stiffness.
Table 1.
The equivalent stiffness found via the global stiffness iteration method
xc ρ k∧eq
0.0 0.0 0.0281
0.001 0.0032 0.0279
0.05 0.1602 0.0203
0.1 0.3204 0.0136

sec.title: 3. Cracked beam with the switching crack model
sec.p:
The same approach is now utilized for finding an approximation to the GEBSM and its corresponding modes and frequencies for a beam with a switching crack. The state of the switching crack in the cracked beam shown in Figure 8(a) depends on the difference between the rotational degrees of freedom of the cracked element, as shown in Figure 8(c). Using this condition, the switching between the crack states is captured for all time steps within a full period of oscillation. If the element j in the FEM of the cracked beam has a switching crack, the difference between the rotational degrees of freedom of this cracked element is Φj=φj+1-φj, while the switching condition is given as (11)φj+1-φj>Φc closed stateφj+1-φj≤Φc open state where Φc is the rotational degree-of-freedom difference for which the crack changes its state. Figure 8.
(a) Fixed-free beam with switching crack. (b) Direction of the coordinates. (c) Rotational coordinates of the cracked element. (c) Four-degrees-of-freedom local equivalent linear stiffness method (LELSM) model.

The area moment of inertia of the transverse cross-section of the uncracked beam is I, while the area moment of inertia of the cracked element cross-section can be written as Ic=μcI, where μc is the percentage of reduction in the area moment of inertia due to the appearance of the crack. Hence, the cracked element stiffness matrix has two states. The element stiffness matrix for a fully closed crack state is given by (12)kj=EIl3[126l-126l6l4l2-6l2l2-12-6l12-6l6l2l2-6l4l2]
while the stiffness matrix for a fully open crack state is (13)(kc)j=μcEIl3[126l-126l6l4l2-6l2l2-12-6l12-6l6l2l2-6l4l2]

The LELSM requires setting all coordinates to zero except for the cracked element itself, as previously shown in Figure 1(b). Hence, the four degree-of-freedom undamped equations of motion resulting from the application of the LELSM, as in Figure 8(d), using the lumped-mass matrix are given as (14)ρAl[10000l212000010000l212][u··jφ··ju··j+1φ··j+1]+EIl3[12(μ+1)6l(μ-1)-12μ6μl6l(μ-1)4l2(μ+1)-6μl2μl2-12μ-6μl12(μ+1)-6l(μ-1)6μl2μl2-6l(μ-1)4l2(μ+1)][ujφjuj+1φj+1]=[0000] where μ=μc for the fully open crack state and μ=1 for the fully closed crack state. The LELSM equations of motion of the cracked element are reduced to a two-degrees-of-freedom system for Φj=φj+1-φj and Ψj=uj+1+uj as (15a)ρAl312Φ··j+EIl3(2(μ(Φj)+2)l2Φj+6lΨj)=0 (15b)ρAlΨ··j+EIl3(6lΦj+12Ψj)=0 where μ(Φj)={1Φj>ΦcμcΦj≤Φc

The formula of the approximate bilinear frequencies of the system in Equation (15) was previously given in Equation (9), where ω-i is the ith mode frequency of the system in the first linear sub-region Φj≤Φc, ω+i is the ith mode frequency of the system in the second linear sub-region Φc<Φj, γi=ω+i/ω-i, ρ=Φc/Φj(0) and Φj(0)=φj+1(0)-φj(0), which is calculated based on choosing the first linear mode as the initial condition.

The first and second bilinear frequencies of the system in Equation (15) are found to be exactly the same as the first and the third bilinear frequencies of the system in Equation (14). For vanishing clearance (i.e. Φc=0) the local bilinear frequency in Equation (9) was reduced to Equation (10).

The proposed approach proceeds as in Section 2 by finding μeq (μc<μeq<1) to obtain a local equivalent stiffness matrix approximation to the bilinear cracked system. This local equivalent stiffness matrix (keq)j gives nearly similar local bilinear frequencies to those obtained by Equation (9) of the bilinear system of the stiffness matrix in Equation (14). Hence, the bilinear stiffness matrix in Equation (14) can be replaced by the local equivalent bilinear stiffness matrix as (16)(keq)j=EIl3[12(μeq+1)6l(μeq-1)-12μeq6μeql6l(μeq-1)4l2(μeq+1)-6μeql2μeql2-12μeq-6μeql12(μeq+1)-6l(μeq-1)6μeql2μeql2-6l(μeq-1)4l2(μeq+1)]
Finding such local equivalent bilinear stiffness matrix for the local bilinear system yields the N×N GEBSM of the cracked beam with N elements in Figure 8(a).

sec.title: 3.1. Spring-mass system with switching stiffness
sec.p:
The proposed approach for finding the GEBSM of the beam with a switching crack can be applied here to the spring-mass system with switching stiffness. For the 20-degrees-of-freedom spring-mass system in Figure 9(a) the masses j-1, j, j+1 and j+2 are connected by a variable stiffness spring of kv=μck. Similar to the beam with switching crack, Zc is the predefined value of the relative displacement between the degrees-of-freedom j and j+1 for which the stiffness value switches betweenk and kv. If Zj=xj+1-xj and Zj>Zc, then μ=1, whileμ=μc for Zj≤Zc for 0≤μc<1. Figure 9.
(a) The 20-degrees-of-freedom spring-mass system with variable stiffness kv between masses j-1 and j+1. (b) The local equivalent linear stiffness method (LELSM) model of the system.

The application of the LELSM requires setting all coordinates to zero except those attached to the springs of variable stiffness, as shown in Figure 9(b). This yields the 4×4 stiffness matrix k∧j as (17)k∧j=[k(1+μ)-μk00-μk2μk-μk00-μk2μk-μk00-μkk(1+μ)]

Similar to the beam with a switching crack, the bilinear frequency relations in Equations (9) and (10) can be applied for finding a local equivalent4×4 bilinear stiffness matrix as (18)(keq)j=[k(1+μeq)-μeqk00-μeqk2μeqk-μeqk00-μeqk2μeqk-μeqk00-μeqkk(1+μeq)] where μc<μeq<1.

sec.title: 3.2. Finding the local and the global equivalent bilinear stiffness matrices
sec.p: The GEBSM is calculated numerically by finding μeq using two different methods.

Method 1: Local iteration in the 4×4 stiffness matrix in Equation (16) of the cracked beam or Equation (18) of the bilinear spring-mass system for finding μeq.
Calculate the four approximate values of the bilinear frequencies (Ωi for i=1,2,…,4) of the four-degrees-of-freedom system resulting from LELSM application using the PMM in Equation (9) for the nonvanishing clearance or Equation (10) for the vanishing clearance.
Find the equivalent μeq such that 0<μeq<μc, for which the 4×4 stiffness matrix in Equation (16) for a switching crack or Equation (18) for a switching stiffness has four approximate eigenfrequencies (Ω~i for i=1,2,…,n) such that ∑i=1nwi|Ωi-Ω~i| is minimized by the iteration on Equation (16) or (18).
As the optimum value of μeq is obtained, the GEBSM stiffness is updated with this optimum value. The 4×4 equivalent stiffness matrix in Equation (16) of the cracked beam or that in Equation (18) of the bilinear spring-mass system replaces the corresponding elements in the global n×n stiffness matrix of the full system while the GEBSM stiffness is formed.
The modes of the mass-normalized GEBSM are compared with the corresponding updated LELSM modes and the POMs of the system.

Method 2: Global iteration in the n×n stiffness matrix for finding μeq.
Calculate the set of n approximate values of the bilinear frequencies (Ωi, i=1,2,…,n) of the system with switching crack or stiffness using the PMM in Equation (9) for the nonvanishing clearance or Equation (10) for the vanishing clearance.
The 4×4 stiffness matrix in Equation (16) of the cracked beam or that in Equation (18) of the bilinear spring-mass system replaces the corresponding elements in the global n×n stiffness matrix of the full system while the GEBSM stiffness is formed.
Find the equivalent μeq such that 0<μeq<μc, for which the n×n mass-normalized GEBSM stiffness matrix has a set ofn approximate eigenfrequencies (Ω~i,i=1,2,…,n) such that ∑i=1nwi|Ωi-Ω~i| is minimized by the iteration on the global n×n stiffness matrix of the full system.
As the optimum value of μeq is obtained, the GEBSM stiffness is updated at this optimum value.
The modes of the mass-normalized GEBSM are compared with the corresponding updated LELSM modes and the POMs of the system.
The value for μeq obtained using Method 2 tends to be slightly more accurate than that obtained via local iteration on the 4×4 stiffness matrix in Method 1.

sec.title: 3.3. Examples
sec.p:
Example 1: The 20-degrees-of-freedom spring-mass system shown in Figure 9(a) is considered here. For this example, m=1, k=1, μc=0.5, Zc=0 (vanishing clearance) and j=9. The local bilinear frequencies are calculated using Equation (10) for i=1,2,…,4. The equivalent value of μ is found via Method 1 to be μeq=0.6863, which is used for calculating (keq)j. This local equivalent 4×4 bilinear stiffness matrix (keq)j replaces the corresponding elements in the global linear stiffness matrix K to form the GEBSM. The results in Figures 10(a) and (b) show that the GEBSM frequencies are highly accurate in approximating the global bilinear frequencies via Equation (10). In addition, the first two BLMs of the GEBSM closely approximate the corresponding POMs, as shown in Figure 11(a) for the first mode and 11(b) for the second mode, when linear modes are selected as initial conditions. Figure 10.
(a) Comparison between the approximated bilinear frequencies calculated via Equation (10) and the frequencies calculated based on the mass-normalized global equivalent bilinear stiffness matrix (GEBSM) found via Method 1. (b) Relative error between these frequencies.
Figure 11.
Comparison between the proper orthogonal modes (POMs) and the bilinear modes calculated based on the mass-normalized global equivalent bilinear stiffness matrix (GEBSM) found via Method 1: (a) first mode; (b) second mode.

Example 2: The beam in Figure 8(a) with a switching crack in element 5 is considered here with Φc=0 (vanishing clearance). For this example, the beam is divided into 10 elements, where EI=1, ρA=1 and μc=0.5. The bilinear frequencies are calculated using Equation (10) for i=1,2,…,20, where their equivalent frequencies are calculated for the GEBSM Keq via Method 2 for finding μeq. The equivalent value of μ is found to be μeqg=0.6674, which is used for calculating (keq)j for the cracked element. This local equivalent 4×4 bilinear stiffness matrix replaces the corresponding elements in the global linear stiffness matrix K of the cracked beam to form the GEBSM. The results in Figures 12(a) and (b) show that the GEBSM is accurate in retrieving the global bilinear frequencies obtained via Equation (10). In addition, the first two BLMs of the GEBSM are close to the corresponding POMs, as shown in Figures 13(a) and (b). Figure 12.
(a) Comparison between the approximate bilinear frequencies calculated via Equation (10) and the frequencies of the mass-normalized global equivalent bilinear stiffness matrix (GEBSM) of a cracked beam found using Method 2 for μc=0.5. (b) Relative error between these frequencies.
Figure 13.
Comparison between the proper orthogonal modes (POMs) and the bilinear modes of the mass-normalized global equivalent bilinear stiffness matrix (GEBSM) of the cracked beam with switching crack for μc=0.5: (a) first mode; (b) second mode.

The comparison between Method 1 and Method 2 for finding the GEBSM is shown in Figure 14. It is shown that Method 2 is more accurate than Method 1, especially for the first five transverse modes, where the error between the retrieved frequencies from the GEBSM and the bilinear frequencies is nearly equal or less than 0.2% (99.8% accuracy). In addition, Method 2 is found to be slightly more accurate in approximating the first BLM, as shown in Figure 15, and the second BLM in Figure 16 for μc=0.75. Figure 14.
Comparison between the frequencies calculated based on Method 1 and Method 2 and the bilinear frequencies calculated via Equation (10) for μc=0.5.
Figure 15.
Comparison between the first proper orthogonal mode (POM) and the first bilinear mode of the mass-normalized global equivalent bilinear stiffness matrix (GEBSM) of the cracked beam with a switching crack: (a) Method 1; (b) Method 2.
Figure 16.
Comparison between the second proper orthogonal mode (POM) and the second bilinear mode of the mass-normalized global equivalent bilinear stiffness matrix (GEBSM) of the cracked beam with a switching crack: (a) Method 1; (b) Method 2.

sec.title: 4. Spring-mass and beam systems with mixed clearance and cubic nonlinearities
sec.p:
In this section, we explore the possibility of finding a GELSM of spring-mass and beam systems with mixed nonlinearities (i.e. clearance and cubic nonlinearities), as shown in Figure 17. Finding this matrix requires first finding the GEBSM using Method 2, which including only the effect of clearance nonlinearity. Then the LELSM is applied to the GEBSM for finding linear equivalent stiffnesses for the nonlinear springs that are used for modeling the boundary damages. As a result, the GELSM is obtained, which includes the effect of the mixed nonlinearities. The approximate BLMs in Figure 18, which are obtained via the GELSM, have been found to be nearly equal to the corresponding POMs for the 20-degrees-of-freedom spring-mass system in Figure 17 with assumed vanishing clearance nonlinearity at μc=0.5, and a cubic spring is attached to the right of mass m20 with cubic spring of ɛ=1. Similar conclusions are also observed for the cracked beam with a switching crack of μc=0.5 and cubic spring of ɛ=1 attached to the free end, where the GEBSM and the GELSM modes have been found to be nearly equivalent to the POMs, as shown in Figure 19. Hence, the application of Method 2 and the LELSM on the dynamic systems with mixed clearance and cubic nonlinearities is found to be efficient in the approximation of the BLMs and their corresponding frequencies where, unlike POD, no a priori simulation is required. Figure 17.
(a) The 20-degrees-of-freedom spring-mass system with variable stiffness kv between masses j-1 and j+1 and cubic spring attached to m20. (b) A fixed-free beam with switching crack in element 5 and cubic spring attached to the free end.
Figure 18.
Comparison between the proper orthogonal modes (POMs) and the bilinear modes that are calculated based on the mass-normalized global equivalent linear stiffness matrix (GELSM) for the 20 degree-of-freedom spring-mass system in Figure 17(a) with vanishing clearance and cubic nonlinearities.
Figure 19.
Comparison between the proper orthogonal modes (POMs) and the bilinear modes that are calculated based on mass-normalized global equivalent linear stiffness matrix (GELSM) for the cracked beam with: (a) vanishing clearance; (b) vanishing clearance and damaged boundary (cubic nonlinearities).

sec.title: 5. Cracked beam with nonvanishing clearance
sec.p:
The 10-element fixed-free beam in Figure 17(b) with a switching crack of a nonvanishing clearance in element 5 is reconsidered here. The approximated values for the bilinear frequencies are calculated using Equation (9). The GEBSM is found by Method 2 at these frequencies. It is shown that application of the LELSM yields the system in Equation (15), from which the formula α=3/(μc+2) is found. Finding this formula for α enables the application of the bilinear frequencies in Equation (9) for a cracked beam with a transverse switching crack of a nonvanishing clearance. These frequencies and the corresponding GEBSM frequencies are plotted in Figure 20 for different values of clearance Φc. It is found that the accuracy in approximating the GEBSM by the bilinear frequencies of Equation (9) is also found to be excellent for different values of nonvanishing clearance. The value of μeq in the GEBSM for each case in Figure 20 is shown in Table 2. Figure 20.
Comparison between the frequencies of the mass-normalized global equivalent bilinear stiffness matrix (GEBSM) found via Method 2 and the bilinear frequencies calculated via Equation (9) for μc=0.5 of the 10-element beam with switching crack at element 5 of (a) vanishing clearance and (b)–(d) nonvanishing clearance.
Table 2.
The values of μeq in the global equivalent bilinear stiffness matrix for each case in Figure 20
Φc(rad) Φc(Degrees) ρ μeq
0.0000 0.0000 0.0000 0.6671
0.0005 0.0286 0.0908 0.6425
0.0010 0.0573 0.1816 0.6198
0.0050 0.2865 0.9080 0.5041

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: The dynamic system with switching stiffness and a beam with a switching crack and damaged boundary have been addressed in this paper. A novel technique is introduced for finding the GEBSM based on utilizing the bilinear frequency approach. The bilinear frequency formula is found to be efficient in approximating the bilinear frequencies of a cracked beam or multi-degrees-of-freedom dynamic system with a bilinear switching stiffness. The finite element stiffness matrix of the cracked element with a switching crack has been utilized via the LELSM, which resulted in applying the bilinear frequency formulas for the vanishing and nonvanishing clearance with the correct condition of the switching crack. The multi-degrees-of-freedom bilinear frequency formula has been applied through two new methods to large-scale bilinear systems for finding the GEBSM. These methods have been found to be efficient in approximating the GEBSM for these systems. The BLMs of the mass-normalized GEBSM are found to have an excellent agreement with their corresponding POMs. In addition, for the dynamic systems with mixed bilinear (vanishing or nonvanishing clearance) and cubic nonlinearities (boundary damage), the GEBSM was found first and then employed with the LELSM for finding the GELSM, which includes the effect of both bilinear and cubic nonlinearities. The modes and their corresponding frequencies of the mass-normalized GELSM are found to be accurate in approximating the bilinear behavior of the considered dynamic systems with these mixed nonlinearities.

The GEBSM and GELSM modes are verified via POMs while, unlike POMs, finding these linear equivalent stiffness matrices and their corresponding modes does not require a priori simulation. The good agreement between the mass-normalized GELSM and GEBSM modes with the corresponding POMs has verified the capability of the proposed techniques. Moreover, finding the GEBSM and GELSM for the beam with a switching crack and damaged boundary based on the bilinear frequency approach and the LELSM made it possible to approximate the BLMs of the system, which can be considered as a good linear approximation to the corresponding nonlinear normal modes similar to the use of POMs.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
